title: Judge Calls Venezuela's $1 Billion Nonpayment to Creditor an Affront to U.S. Courts
summary: A federal judge established a sale process for Venezuela's stake in Citgo Petroleum, though no transaction can occur under current Treasury Department rules. A federal judge ordered that Venezuela's stake in oil refiner Citgo Petroleum Corp. be put up for sale to satisfy creditors, calling the country's nonpayment an affront while acknowledging that no auction can occur under current U.S. sanctions.

title: Biden's First 10 Days to Focus on Covid-19, Economy
summary: New administration aims to reverse many of Trump's policies with flurry of executive actions. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden's transition team is outlining plans to reverse many of President Trump's policies during the first 10 days of the new administration, including a flurry of executive actions focused on Covid-19, the economy and climate change.

title: Donald Tober, Marketer of Sweet'N Low, Dies at 89
summary: New York entrepreneur, whose Sugar Foods distributed restaurant supplies, made the artificial sweetener a fixture on tabletops. Donald Tober, whose Sugar Foods Corp. marketed the Sweet'N Low sugar substitute and other restaurant supplies, died Friday in what New York police described as a suicide. He was 89.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Selection of photos from Jan. 10 through Jan. 16 by The Wall Street Journal's photo editors. River Bailey, a 41-year-old software developer, says she doesn't know if she would have come out as trans at work if not for her ability to work from her home in central Texas. 'It gave me the freedom to just be able to exist,' she says. Read more.

title: Palestinian Leader Calls First Vote in 15 Years, Amid Hopes to Heal Rift With U.S.
summary: The ballot could help bolster ties with the Biden administration, but divisions between Fatah and Hamas could yet scuttle the election. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas announced plans for parliamentary and presidential elections for the first time in about 15 years, as the Palestinians seek to rebuild its ties with President-elect Joe Biden after falling out with the Trump administration.

title: Fiat Chrysler, PSA Group Merge to Create New Auto-Making Behemoth
summary: The newly formed auto maker, called Stellantis, to start trading Monday in Europe and Tuesday in New York.

title: Ugandan President Claims Sixth Election Victory
summary: The violent race pitched one of Africa's longest-serving leaders against a populist whose message of change galvanized the country's youth. KAMPALA, Uganda-President Yoweri Museveni was declared the winner of his sixth consecutive presidential election on Saturday, while opposition leader Bobi Wine alleged the vote was rigged, capping a divisive campaign marred by government repression, an internet shutdown and the country's worst political violence for decades.

title: New York Looks to Move Past Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout's Troubled First Weeks
summary: Governor changed course on eligibility following bumpy month in which some officials said mismanagement caused delays and waste. This week, Gov. Andrew Cuomo reversed New York's approach on the Covid-19 vaccine, loosening eligibility requirements to anyone age 65 and up.

title: Pro-Trump Discussion Board Faces Possible Shutdown
summary: Web-hosting company says TheDonald.Win must clean up; domain's owner says he has effectively lost control of it. An influential pro-Trump discussion board active in the buildup to the Jan. 6 Capitol attack faces the prospect of being shut down by its web-hosting company for allegedly fostering white supremacist and violent extremism.

title: Solo Extremists Might Pose Higher Risk Than Organized Groups
summary: Far-right leaders urge followers to stay away from capitals where law-enforcement presence will be high through the presidential inauguration. As Washington, D.C., and state capitals enact security measures, solo actors may pose a threat in coming weeks as extremist groups are advising followers to avoid large rallies but remain opposed to the incoming administration, according to people who track such groups.

summary: Regulators say consumers often pay too much for the price of convenience in food delivery. American consumers have been forced to eat food-delivery costs sometimes nearly as big as the meals themselves. Regulators are fed up.

title: Switzerland to Hold Referendum on Covid-19 Lockdown
summary: The vote, which could be held as soon as June, tests government's legal powers and is latest example of Switzerland's direct democracy. Switzerland's system of direct democracy will be put to the test again later this year, this time with a referendum on whether to roll back the government's powers to impose lockdowns and other measures to slow the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Merkel's Party Chooses Continuity by Appointing Centrist Leader
summary: New party chairman Armin Laschet is expected to adopt the German chancellor's legacy of middle-of-the-road pragmatism. BERLIN-Angela Merkel's conservatives opted for continuity on Saturday when they elected as party chairman a centrist who will now likely run as her successor for chancellor in the September election.

title: Chinese Property Developers Have Huge Debts to Refinance
summary: The country's real-estate firms need to repay up to an estimated $53.5 billion of offshore debt this year. China's property developers have a mountain of international debt to refinance this year, and tight lending conditions are raising the risk of defaults.

title: Groceries Prove a Pandemic Bright Spot for BP and Shell
summary: Oil majors bet offering more fresh food and services at gas-station stores can help offset declining oil income. LONDON-Coffee and groceries are becoming a bigger part of BP PLC and Royal Dutch Shell PLC's bottom line.

title: U.A.E. Pushes Ahead With Chinese Covid-19 Vaccine

title: U.S. Executes Last Federal Inmate of Trump's Term
summary: Dustin Higgs, the 13th and final federal inmate to die before President Trump leaves office, was executed after the Supreme Court gave its approval. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department early Saturday executed Dustin Higgs, the 13th and final federal inmate to die before President Trump leaves office and President-elect Joe Biden, an opponent of the death penalty, is sworn in.

title: Foreign Investors Expect the Dollar to Remain Weak Under Biden
summary: Increased stimulus spending could play a role in further softening of the U.S. currency. The view from financial experts abroad is that the dollar, currently near its weakest level in three years, will stay weak, holding on to much of its 2020 decline.

title: Robots Turn 100-and Still Enthrall Us
summary: The intelligent, human-like machines long promised by science fiction still don't exist, but they've played an important role in the modern imagination.. In 2021, robots can be forklifts or machine tools, surgical instruments or bomb defusers. As a viral video showed this month, a new, human-shaped model from Boston Dynamics can even dance to the Motown song "Do You Love Me?" But when the Czech writer Karel Capek coined the word "robot" in his play "R.U.R.," which made its debut in Prague 100 years ago this month, he had something much grander in mind: a new, man-made species, capable of tireless labor but also love, hope and self-sacrifice. As a robot declares in the play's last scene, "We've become beings with souls."

title: An Old Foe of Banks Could Be Wall Street's New Top Cop
summary: Gary Gensler is expected to be Joe Biden's pick to take over the Securities and Exchange Commission. 'He will do things that are controversial.'. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden's expected pick of Gary Gensler to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission could give Wall Street its most aggressive regulator in two decades.

title: Pajamas Are the New Sweatpants-How to Wear Them Everywhere
summary: Men and women are trading their sad WFH uniforms for snazzy sleepwear, spending every waking hour in snugly bliss. These expert tips will help you style PJs for almost any socially distant activity.. PAJAMAS ARE at least partially responsible for keeping Vincent "the Chin" Gigante out of jail for decades. Starting in the 1960s, the late Mr. Gigante, a notorious New York mob boss, feigned mental illness in a surprisingly successful scheme to convince authorities that he couldn't possibly be the head of the Genovese crime family. To keep up appearances, he'd meander through his Greenwich Village neighborhood mumbling to himself while wearing slippers, sleepwear and a bathrobe. His pajama game helped him elude arrest until the 1990s, at which point he was locked up for racketeering and conspiring to murder his Mafioso rivals.

title: Biden Outlines Plan for Bigger Federal Role in Covid-19 Vaccinations
summary: President-elect will expand use of Defense Production Act to increase production of vaccines, vaccination supplies. WILMINGTON, Del.-President-elect Joe Biden outlined his proposal to give the federal government a bigger role in getting Americans vaccinated against Covid-19, including setting up federally supported community centers and mobile clinics for delivering shots.

title: 'QAnon Shaman' Left Pence Threatening Note at Capitol Riot, Prosecutors Say
summary: Judge orders Jacob Chansley held in detention until he faces trial on charges connected to the siege by Trump supporters. title: New York's Covid-19 Vaccinations Hindered by Missteps, Misinformation
summary: Rolling out such a large campaign was always going to be a logistical challenge, but certain problems have made it bumpier. The message went out over social media Thursday afternoon that a mass vaccination site in Brooklyn had spare Covid-19 vaccines that needed to be used, or would go to waste. New Yorkers showed up, only to be met with confusion and turned away.

title: FAA Approves Fully Automated Commercial Drone Flights
summary: American Robotics granted permission to operate drones without hands-on piloting. U.S. aviation regulators have approved the first fully automated commercial drone flights, granting a small Massachusetts-based company permission to operate drones without hands-on piloting or direct observation by human controllers or observers.
